conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
The graph for object B shows a curve that starts with a negative slope, reaches a minimum, and then increases to intersect with the graph of object A at t2.
At t = 0, the slope of the tangent line to the curve is negative.
As time progresses towards t1, the slope of the tangent line becomes less negative, indicating that the acceleration is increasing.
At t1, the curve reaches its minimum point, and the slope of the tangent line is zero, indicating zero acceleration.
Beyond t1, the slope of the tangent line becomes positive and increases, indicating positive acceleration.
From t = 0 to t1, the acceleration of object B is increasing (becoming less negative).
From t1 to t2, the acceleration of object B is positive and continues to increase.
The acceleration of object B starts negative, becomes zero at t1, and then becomes positive and increases until t2.
The acceleration of object B increases from a negative value to a positive value during the time interval from 0 to t2.
